description:
Times marches on and Kam Lok is no longer the hot spot we used to come every Sunday after church services...20+ years ago?!  

It has the typical unadorned, slightly dingy, Chinatown restaurant ambience, and the owner has not done much to make the basement space unique. The tables and chairs are the same ones from years ago. The waitresses seem overworked or at least always bustling about. This being Chinatown, don't expect 4 or 5 star service. Wave one down when you want attention.

Obviously Kam Lok focuses on the local Chinese population, and not the tourist crowd. To stay in business all these years Kam Lok must be doing something right.

Yes, it's all about the inexpensive but authentic Cantonese food. We watched people order beautiful streamed whole fish, stir fried Dungeness crab, and huge oysters in the shell...for lunch!

Everything tasted pretty close to what we remembered from pre-Yelp years. We really came for the San Francisco specialty, Hung Tao Yee Fu Won Ton. It's deep fried won ton in a type of thickened egg drop soup. I haven't found it on the east coast, and it's a must try if you've never eaten it. A San Francisco treat!

The Spicy beef chow fun and the Seafood pan-fried noodles dishes were also tasty, but the special won ton is still their best lunch offering. It's delicious, hits the spot, and we had a double order!
author: Jerry C.

description: Small whole in the wall my ***. The food here is at least only subpar. If you want decent food in Chinatown, go to capital instead. The food here is not great, on top of that, the owner literally charges everyone different prices for the food. They charged me 8.70. As I went back to eat my lunch, my colleague told me that he was charged 8.30, and my other colleague that they knew was charged only 7.30... I understand that it's your business but at least be honest with everyone about pricing. So people beware, if you wanna be charged for extra and be unfairly treated, this place is just the right place for you.
author: Elsa W.

description:
Yes, it is in a basement. It is old school chinatown cantonese comfort food for me. Don't expect ambiance but a mom and pop feel to authentic family style food. I ordered some take out and was not disappointed on how much food I got for the price.

Liked:
- beef chow fun
- BBQ pork and tofu over rice
- came with house soup

Meh
- ambiance

I am a fan. I don't need the frills in chinatown, just good food. Price is right and the people are friendly but then again, I am in the tribe.
author: Steve L.

description: Small, Hole in the Wall Place in Chinatown. Came Here based on positive review from Lyft Driver, Jordan! Little Ambiance but the Food Was GREAT! We ordered the Wonton Soup with Pork, was Excellent! Potstickers, Unremarkable... and Then there was the DRY SPARERIBS WITH SPICY SALT! They Were The BEST! So Crispy. Like eating Pork in the form of Crispy Chicken Skin or Really Good, Super Thin Chicharrones That where Cooked to Perfection. Simply Garnished with Green Onions and thinly sliced Jalapeños,  Out of this World! YOU GOTTA TRY THIS. Also ordered a cup of Sweet and Sour Sauce to dip them in. You Won't Be Sorry!
author: Tina J.

description:
The place might turn you off, but this feels homey for some reason. Elderly chinese kadies chopping veggies in one table, a young mom who is ther server, cashier, busboy help her kids settle in after school (she serves fast and knows the menu by heart- like that asian grandmother that feeds you till you drop). Tables are kept clean so that's good. 

Food are cooked as you order i believe based on the action in the kitchen i hear as you order, food served steaming hot at reasonable speed.

Food are well cooked- nothing extra special. But it gives that at home cooking feel, no msg inducing head ache feel, no grease. Balanced taste, just right taste. Gives you that satisfied feeling.

They also remember you as their customer. One time they even gave me an off menu dessert they were had for their personal food.
author: Kruting K.

description: Old school authentic Chinese food- if you know what to order. Highly recommend their ginger scallion oysters. Took me years to find this taste and type of oyster again.
author: Ernest M.

description: This is one of my favorite places in China town for local Cantonese style food. Don't expect decent service, but if you're looking for good Chinese food at really low prices this is the place to go. Yes it's in a basement, hence you won't see many non Chinese there, but it's a real gem.
author: David L.

description:
can I give negative star? really bad service and rude, we went on a supper hot day in SF, about 103F. There is no ac in the restaurant and the waitress gave us a pot of hot-tea, we asked the old bald man at the counter for iced water, he showed his impatient face and walked away, after waited for several minute, he came with a tap water, no ice at all!  Fine, I forgave him.

When we were ready to order, we waved to him, he walked away and we have to call him again, he came with his fiery face, showing his impatient and frown.  That's it, I decided not to order and told him we're leaving because he was rude, we walked away, he was screaming something like "go, go don't come".  Really rude. I wish I took a picture of him to show it here with my review.
author: Joyce T.

description:
Eh, this place was ok. It's in a basement, which I kinda thought was cool - like oh a hidden gem - but it's sorta dingy down there. Ordered fried squid as an appetizer, and it was super delicious!! Fried well, not too heavy or greasy, crisp. Very good. Then came the beef curry clay pot meal I got. The actual meat was good, but there was a lot of fat on the meat. The curry of it was pretty okay, but I've had better. At least the food was relatively cheap.

tl;dr
ambience - meh
tea - watery
fried squid - very good
beef curry in the clay pot - a lot of fat on the meat
not planning on going go back
author: Jen A.

description:
You want authentic, you've got authentic. This place was PACKED with Chinese families, Chinese men, Chinese people. Everyone here was literally Chinese except for my boyfriend and me. We were walking around Chinatown taking in the sights and we had no idea where to go for dinner. We hear a lot of noise coming from downstairs and so we decided to check it out. First glance we saw that it was packed so to us that was a good sign. A grandmother was reading the newspaper at a table and one of the ladies scooted her out so we could sit...kind of awkward but I guess they wanted to make room for paying customers. 

So here's the deal. You can't come to a place like this and expect superb service and five star dining. You have to take it for what it's worth and understand the culture. One of the waitresses luckily spoke well enough English so we were able to order from her. Some of the other ladies did not so we had to point and smile and nod but they were very accommodating and eventually brought us whatever we needed, like ice water instead of tea. They don't come by and ask you if you need anything. If you need something you wave someone down. They are super busy and won't bother you if you don't bother them. Unfortunately when they were clearing our dishes a little bit of sauce from the plate splattered on my boyfriend but hey, it's fine because you have to lower your expectations.

Food: Menu is huge but there are a lot of repeat items. They have traditional dishes as well as some Americanized dishes all at a very low cost. Also, the portions are large. A soup cost around $6 and I figured it would just be a small bowl but it was a decent size bowl meant for sharing. Family style is very common in Asian cuisine. So we kind of went a little overboard since everything was so inexpensive and ordered enough food for a family of 5 for just my boyfriend and me. The spring rolls were good, nice and crispy. The pan fried dumplings were also good with a decent filling but they didn't come with any sauce. So they were a tad bland. I order a wonton soup with vegetables. The broth was clear, clean, and savory. Fresh vegetables and nice size wontons. I was impressed with the freshness of the vegetables and really enjoyed my soup. I also ordered Chinese broccoli with garlic sauce. Huge portion and perfectly blanched with a nice crunch (so not too soggy) and you could really taste the garlic which I love. My boyfriend took a dive and ordered something unusual. I think he was imagining something different. It was some type of meat and tofu in a clay dish. He said he really liked the sauce, it was a think gravy sauce which was different and maybe not his favorite consistency, almost gelatinous, but the taste he enjoyed. It was neat to try something maybe more traditional. 

Overall we were pleased with our experience and have stories to share about our time in Chinatown. If you want to get out of your comfort zone and dine with Chinese families, come to Kam Lok.
author: Debi N.

description:
A sign for dungeness crab lured my family into Kam Lok. My mom wanted wonton noodles, so we were originally supposed to go elsewhere. That is, until she saw the sign for a $38 five course meal that included crab. My parents and I walked in on Wednesday, December 2nd at 6pm for dinner.

$38 set dinner menu:
*Salt and pepper crab
*Peking spareribs
*Beef clay pot
*Diced chicken with corn soup
*Garlic with mustard greens

The meal originally came with salt and pepper crab, but we got ginger scallion crab instead as I like it prepared that way better. The crab was a good size. It could have been wok fried a little better to bring out the flavor, but still a good dish. The adore chicken corn soup, so this was a good start to our meal. The mustard greens were a nice portion though a tad mushy. Still good garlic flavor. The clay pot was alright. Kind of small, but still more than enough to feed the 3 of us. I didn't try the spareribs as I don't like the sweet and sour sauce.

My mom saw another restaurant patron order chow mein. It looked like it was fried perfectly, so she decided to order the Beef chow fun with bean sprouts ($6). This was my favorite dish. The noodles had a nice chew. And it was dry fried perfectly. Good flavor as well.

Surprising find in Chinatown. I'd go again as it's been hard to find decently priced dungeness crab. And that beef chow fun?! Yum!
author: Elena N.

description: Wondered around Chinatown and ended up here. Has the normal Chinese food and some more exotic options. Everything was very good, won ton soup best I've had.
author: Steve C.

description:
One of best meals in Chinatown in recent memory @ Bargain prices.

Don't expect fancy service.  or much service at all for that matter.  ;)  lol.  To get a table, you need to be aggressive and make sure one of the locals and regulars do not cut you.  Got to the register and tell them you have party of X.

After being seated... if you need something, raise your hand and ask... no they will not refill your tea automatically without you popping the lid open.  This is not your fancy smancy deal but solid, fresh, Chinese food at great prices.  

All dishes are GOOD and arrived promptly.  The menu and the few pictures does not do their food justice.  

Don't be afraid to ask "what's in season" and "what's good today".  Crabs or live fish are excellent here at super reasonable prices.  In season for the winter... crab, clams and escargot!

This place is PACKED a lot of times; you have to be aggressive and walk up to the cashier/ waitress lady in the back to let her know that you need a table.  Otherwise, you will get cut left and right by locals and regular patrons... and sorry, yes, especially if you don't speak the language.  

Similar dishes at R&G or Great Eastern would cost you 3x.  We had a great meal here... Highly recommended!
author: Winnie W.

description: Dirty but authentic.  Packed with Chinese peeps always for a reason.  Cheap.
author: Peter S.

description:
We had a party of twelve for lunch last week. We ordered many dishes, Mostly pre order dishes. The food was good and tasty!  Afterwards a surprise birthday cake we bought to restaurant for a friend was served by the waitress. Smooth!
Thank You!
author: dan w.

description: Food was ok.  Pretty average....the bathroom was disgusting.  The service was meh.  Felt like we were bothering one of the ladies when we asked her for forks and water.
author: Linda M.

description: $45 for either a crab or a lobster set meal, so it was definitely quite a bargain!  The lobster was fresh and it had great flavoring.  The set came with four other dishes:  East Lake Beef soup, Mongolia Beef, Spicy Salt Chicken Wings and Tofu with Veggies.  The soup and the tofu tasted good.  However, I find the beef and chicken wings a bit too salty for me.  It was a nice touch that they had complimentary red bean soup for dessert. The portion size was huge, but somehow, the four of us managed to finished everything! Definitely feels like a hole in the wall restaurant especially the fact that the restaurant is literally underground!  Credit cards are accepted.
author: Johnson K.

description:
Where else in San Francisco can you get a huge hot lunch for $6?

This place is out of the way, which is exactly what drew me into it. The store front is a tiny little stairwell down into darkness. I was expecting a little hole in the wall hidden gem that'd be different from all the others on the street. Actually the dining floor is banquet style and the interior looked like your typical average Chinatown restaurant, but we quickly got seated and set up with our menus and tea.

This place serves decent Chinese-American, pretty typical stuff. The quality of the food was just ok. The spicy eggplant wasn't spicy at all, and some pieces of the eggplant could have been cooked more. But portions were huge and it came out fast. Servers didn't pay much attention to us but whatever. Value was excellent. I'd come back for a cheap no frills meal if I was in the area.
author: Cathy J.

description:
Every time Nick and I venture over to San Francisco, we aim for two things (food-wise): authentic Chinese food and authentic Mexican burritos. For the former, this is the spot we always come. Typically I would knock a star off for a lack of ambiance or less engaging staff. Yes, it's in a basement. Yes, the server sort of drops the plates in front of you and is less-than social. That being said, it's allllmoossttt a part of the experience! Look around the restaurant and notice that you're most likely the only tourist in there. You're surrounded by Chinatown locals grabbing a quick bite. Personally, if you're going for true authenticity with your meal, you don't want a fake, phony, tourist-oriented spot anyway...right? Right?

Prices are awesome, like $6 for an entree (you can't get a full meal in San Francisco anywhere else for those numbers), and the portions are excellent. This is my second time here. The first time I got the curry (which was lovely) and the second time I got the Mongolian Beef (which was even better, wow). Every meal comes with a pot of hot tea to start, which is a nice touch.

Don't bring a date here (unless they're cool and adventurous like us), but if you're looking for a no-frills authentic, cheap, tasty Chinese dish on the go, stop in to Kam Lok.
author: Ashley R.

description: Easy to miss little hole in the wall restaurant in the basement in the streets of Chinatown. This place has cheap eats. It's a hit or miss with some of the dishes, think they have gone down hill from what I remembered. It's not clean and the service isn't the best like most typical Chinatown restaurants. However, with the price you pay, one shouldn't expect a 5 star experience.
author: meL Z.

description: this place was awful i hate it so much it's trapped out its super sketchy in there at night, the bathrooms are super disgusting. The customer service is bad the tank they get your crab/lobster is super dirty. Everything in the restaurant is super dusty nothing is clean. It has a 83 cleaness rating, i don't even know how. There was only one nice worker in there i was lowkey scared. (don't go there even tho it's cheap it's not good) you can pay 25 dollars more to eat somewhere better. I chould eat Mcdonald's over this place.
author: Daddy S.

description: very bad service .. the people are very rude .. they made us wait more than 45 minutes and the food was disgusting .. very dirty and very cold place,. If I could take away stars, I would gladly
author: Frida L.

description:
This place seems to be a favorite among locals. I came here twice and was blown away. Most of the staff here is really quick with what you order. Really like how I have to go some stairs to eat at this place. Sam Wo's was closed so I settle here. There is virtually no tourists here, as a a result I feel at home when I eat here. The food is home style in the sense that it is made with local flavors. This place even tastes better than a place call New WLG. Both are underground but this time place is better. I felt like I was eating with college friend rather than my family or co workers because most of the patrons are young. Good for a lunch break if you work in the city. 
Drawback: the cellular network reception here can  be really poor so plan ahead. You will need to wait a while due to the fact it has a local flavor.
author: Michael W.

description: The basement location is fun, very cozy feel to it. I ordered the Hot & Sour Soup and the Shrimp Fried Rice. The soup was kind of bland but I managed to improve it with soy sauce and chili oil. The fried rice was good but seemed a little burnt and overly salted in egg rich areas. The price for the amount of food is reasonable so will most likely be back again.
author: Daisy T.

description:
The cheetah wanders into the underground.... Unsure of what awaits. Does he run away? Or does he take the leap of faith and go all the way? Obviously as I'm writing now, I leaped. 

Kam lok is a very "out of the way" restaurant, in that you wouldn't immediately notice it if you were just walking the streets of Chinatown and looking for a meal. Nestled between two other stores lies a lone staircase that takes you down into the actual restaurant itself. I wandered in on a chance that I may find some nice diamond in the rough, and while feeling timid at first, I found that I was glad I took the trek down those stairs. 

Pretty extensive Chinese menu with the sort of things you would expect to see in a Chinese restaurant and then some. The lunch specials are what caught my eye and I decided to go for the egg and shrimp with rice special. 

I should mention that the service here is kind of slow and not much special. Seems to be the standard order/eat/leave kind of deal. That being said, the prep time was lightning fast! 

The dish I had was absolutely wonderful and just what I needed for a Thursday afternoon brunch. Price was extremely reasonable as well. The place gets no high points for friendly service or cleanliness, but if you want something cheap, filling, and quick that doesn't lack flavor, Kam Lok is the place to go. I will definitely make a return trip sometime when I'm in the area! Want to try some other dishes. 

*chirp!*
author: Jei C.

description:
Worst food I've. Ever had in my life. My mom, older sister and I were in ct just looking for a quick- cheap lunch and we saw this place. When we began walking down the stairs, I noticed the really dingy pink wall paint  and got a sketchy vibe. It was barely 1:00pm and it was packed inside so we just expected it to be a hole in the wall restaurant. (Like all those elite yelp reviewers call it) When we were seated, we were immediately given a menu (that's a good thing). But the staff were no where to be found. We waited for the staffs to come over but they kept walking around, talking to other customers. Finally, we waved one of them over and placed our order. We got a beef fried rice, some sort of lo mein that's usually expensive [I'm not sure the name] and a chicken crispy fried noodle. When a waitress in a blue hoodie came over to scoop our  soup into bowls, my mother said it was fine and we could scoop it our selves politely. The woman immediately dropped the ladle and walked away. No smile, no response, just dropped the ladle, turned around and left. Ok whatever we brushed that off- no biggie. The soup was alright. The first dsh that came was the lo mein. It was obviously made from one of those store bought fried lobster noodles that were reconstituted(I could've made it better at home). And they carelessly cooked the noodles so that it was still chewy. It's not supposed to be chewy. A few CANNED mushroom slices were thrown on top along with a few 呀菜. Nothing else. Just 芽菜and canned mushrooms. Next up was the fried rice. How could you mess that up. It was good but my sisters complaint was that she got 2 LARGE crystals of msg in a bite. (I don't mind msg and expect it anyway so it's whatever). Next came the fried crispy noodles. Classic! But When they were carrying it down to our table, my sister and I made a face to each other about the sour smell coming towards us. We told our mom to take a bite first. She said it was kind of off. Then, I picked some off the plate. THE SAUCE WAS SPOILED. it had gone bad and was such a disappointment. OK well you're probably thinking this review isstupid and nit picky  now but no, there's more. We called over a woman in a red shirt and asked her was it supposed to be sour (spoiled) and she simply responded oh "I don't know, I don't know this dish" and walked away. Moving along, when we got our bill, we told another waitress our noodles were spoiled and it was sour tasting. She said "it's probably the 芽菜, it's definitely the 芽菜. " After that, she also just walked away, not taking the plate, offering a replacement, or apologising. Yes, I know I'm dining at a Chinese restaurant and they don't have perfect service but really, I expect better. I've eaten at plenty of Chinese restaurants but damn it was a really crap experience. 
You usually get what you pay for and for me, I got less that what I paid. The prices really reflect what you get. It's cheap but you get super trash ingredients that are spoiled. These are the kinds of experiences that make me afraid of trying new places.
All in all, it's extremely noisy, dirty, unfriendly, and just remember not to let the prices fool you.
author: Shelly C.

description: Taste not bad but the service is terrible. The only thing that I appreciate is the price. The old man is always bad attitude and never be patient. I definitely will not suggest my friends to go there.
author: Gil C.

description: I've been here twice in the past week and I have no regrets! This place is great for family style dinners and the food is so good! One of my favorite dishes is the claypot fish. Not exactly sure what it is called in English but it is basically an entire fish, about 2-3 pounds, chopped up, battered in flour, and then slowly cooked in a claypot. So good! Another signature dish that I always order at a Chinese restaurant is the broccoli beef and they do not disappoint! They also have some really good soups, I usually go for the soup of the day or the seafood tofu soup, yum! The staff here is friendly and quick, which is great. Not sure if the staff speak any English though but the menus are in both Chinese and English. They also offer complementary tea here which is another plus! Will be back!
author: Lushi Z.

description:
I don't know how this place got 3.5 stars. The service was awful, they were rude and felt unwelcoming. The food was not great as well, I got shrimp fried rice and it was the most tasteless shrimp fried rice I've ever had. 
Not sure how you can make rice TASTELESS but they managed to do that. Not pleased. 
Would not go again or recommend.
author: Antonella A.

description: This is a great, classic mom'n'pop Chinese restaurant, very tasty dishes and very friendly staff.
author: M A.

description: Best chinese food I've tasted.  Tasted home made, authentic and lots of food given for the price. We had to wait a bit for seats because it was packed but it was well worth the wait. Hidden gem in the heart of chinatown. When you see a lot of Asians at a Chinese restaurant, you know the food is going to be mm mm good!
author: S A.

description: Love this place. The salt and pepper crab is delicious. This is not your typical Chinatown tourist trap. The restaurant workers are friendly and want you to leave happy. The spare ribs are incredible. I also loved the vegetable dishes. Don't skip this place. You won't be sorry. Authentic food and great prices.
author: Amy H.

description: Horrible customer service. Me and my boyfriend came in to this place. The lady located us to a table. Once we had our mind set on what we wanted to order we sat there waiting. 10 minutes went by they didn't even bothered asking us what we wanted to order, I decided to wait a little longer. Then 20 minutes went by. I just had enough of the waiting. The lady was walking around deliberately paid us no mind. I would understand if it was busy but it was just us there. Horrible Horrible service I recommend no one going there.
author: Andrea C.

description:
the salt & pepper pork spareribs are disgusting!!!! it is dry as heck. thin piece of chop deep stir fried without any batter. as u can imagine the product are bone dry burnt chops!! i asked for more garlic & that lady looked at me & said, "there's no garlic"... come to think of it, that should've been a clue for me to get the fhuck out!!! ate the chop & sure enough i knew i've been had. ate 1/3 of the portion & couldn't take it anymore so it went in the trash!!!!
i am a local here my whole life & i've tried all the places in C-town. i can tell u this place is just garbage, a typical tourist rip off place.. there are better restaurants in Jackson St, between Grant & Kearny.
author: Forrest G.

description:
After a day of dancing at a music festival on treasure island, friends and I needed some warm, comforting grub as the evening got cold and foggy. The restaurant next door to Kam Lok, Hunan House, was a friend's favorite but was cash only for the night so we had to go next door to this hole-in-the-wall, basement level family restaurant. It looked like one of those places that could either be your ticket to a night of vomiting or the best kept secret in Chinatown.

We ordered the A family style meal, Canton style (the B option is Peking), and it was all right. I'm not the biggest fan of traditional Chinese flavors to be honest, but my friends were all really pleased with our food. 

Almost all that I ate was the dumpling soup, with pork dumplings that were kinda tasteless and mushy, shrimp that were okay but had a slight brightness so I ate a lot of them, bits of cha siu, and veggies.

There was a sweet and sour pork that everyone else enjoyed a lot. The one piece of pork I tried had a lot of connective tissue and more breading than meat. The broccoli beef looked good, and while the sauce was too strong and salty for me, the broccoli was cooked well, not overcooked at all. My friends really loved both the bbq pork fried rice and the chow mein type noodle dish with chicken. There was also an almond chicken dish - I liked the snap peas in that dish a lot. The chicken in all the dishes was just not a good texture to me, but maybe I'm just too picky.

This was definitely a locals kind of place - none of the wait staff was polite or even remotely interested in helping us. We got tsk'ed at for asking for glasses of water for the table and when our friend who speaks Mandarin told someone the food was great, he just kind of glared at her. Oh well.

The meal was cheap, $11.99 per person for the family style meal, and about a dollar more each for tax. 

The main reason for two stars is on the way home, two of us started to feel pretty sick. I never, ever, EVER get sick at restaurants, no matter how much raw fish I eat or how hole-in-the-wall a taco shop is, but the rest of the night my stomach was making noises I have never heard it make and it was just not sitting well with me whatsoever.

The others said they were fine but I just can't believe how bad I still feel, 4 hours later, when all I ate was some soup, shrimp, and veggies I picked out of the broccoli beef and almond chicken dishes. Definitely not coming back here.
author: Keridwyn R.

description: Authentic Chinese experience.  Good food. Wait staff used to tourists but serving In the old world  style.  A lot of food served family style.  Looks like a favorite amongst the locals.
author: Dennis T.

description: The prices are extremely affordable. They have set plates of four for five dishes (including crab or lobster) for $38, which can comfortably feed a group of three. The low prices do draw in some "interesting" patrons who don't know how to control the volumes of their voices and may even drink beyond the point of consciousness, throwing up right in the dining area.
author: Kimberly H.

description:
Tribute review

Date & Time:  Friday, January 20, 2012 @ 11:30 am
Dining Co.:  none, take-out
Scene:  One single table - five neighborhood guys in 40's and 50's at a round, center table eating Wo Choy (family-style preset) menu with BYOB Hennessy.
Decor:  Dive
Service:  Like home with the cousins
Total:  Priceless

*** Dedicated to Genvieve (http://www.yelp.com/user_details?userid=_aSs5dSAabuwnXUGBPzASw) for her incomparable format. 

*** I miss your reviews!
author: Mike C.

description:
Hidden gem in Chinatown.

Other restaurant cannot compare to this basement restaurant.  
Fresh and delicious .
author: Anney T.

description: Cute little restaurant. Found it on accident looking for another basement restaurant. Food was great and cheap and quickly served. Its a really casual place with friendly people who don't like to bother you much during your meal but if you get just the tea you don't need to ask for refills- it's right there! It's also family owned so people are very often coming in and out but it was no biggie for me
author: Bev S.

description:
Food is ok. 
I'd a rather eaten somewhere else. 
What really turned me off is the atmosphere. 
It is seriously lacking ambiance. 
The restroom is naaaaasty. 
I don't know how it even passes for healt inspection.
author: Melissa S.

description: Srimp fried rice was my choice woth Tungstao beer plus egg roll .taste great.very very fresh and perfect balance of flavors. Hole in the wall for chinesse food and prices go U$6.00 per plate if you go two or three blocks at the other chinesse restaurants they will charge U$ 18.00 for the same dish. Just a original chinesse place to eat cheap and good.
author: Gus e.

description: Mongolian beef and sweet and sour pork are absolute musts. The chicken chow mein and potstickers were just okay but overall this was some of the best Chinese food I've had in the Bay Area. Service was quick and the employees were friendly. If you're in San Francisco you should definitely check this place out. Overall I would recommend this to anyone looking for some delicious and authentic Chinese food with great service.
author: Jackie M.

description: Order the $45 meal with the lobster! Walked around trying to decide which place to eat at and glad we chose here. Authentic, quick, wholesome.
author: Weixin D.

description: This place is delicious! If you are looking for great Chinese food in Chinatown that is popular with the local then look no further! They have quick service and are not packed with a ton of tourist.
author: Jessica M.

description:
We had beef and broccoli, Mongolian beef (bomb), pepper fried  fish, chow mein, and some veggie dish with lots of mushrooms.

No, do not be alarmed, it is an basement.  So you will go down some stairs to get down to the restaurant.  I was just checking to see what is on their menu, and some lady kind of took us in.  When you don't feel like paying 10 to 13 dollar for an order of, chow mein, or any plate for that matter, this place is unlike those overpriced Chinese restaurants.   It's cheap and good Chinese food. 

We were starving  and just a little hint, you might not want to bring someone you are trying to impress.  Its kind of dirty but it's for a quick bite to eat with good tasting stuff.
author: Eloy W.

description: Great food, great prices. Large portions and very speedy service. Very kind staff. Highly recommended.
author: Marcio C.

description: Walk downstairs to this restaurant, this place gets packed on a weekend night.  $38 for a set lobster meal for 4 people, cannot beat that!  Includes soup, fried chicken wings, Mongolian beef and tofu with veggies.  You'd need to order steamed rice separately.  They also have a crab version of the set meal for same price.
author: Yvonne L.

description:
I stumbled upon it and kept coming back.  Yes, it is dirty and dingy -- very much so. But the food is excellent and the atmosphere is just what it should be for a hole-in-the-wall, down in the basement local Chinese joint serving a Chinese clientele. 

If I lived in San Fran I'd be a regular. But, I will still be back many times.
author: Ed F.

description: Was in Chinatown looking for a new place to eat that was good for the wallet. A family member suggested me to give Kam Lok a try. I did not notice this place existed as I grew up in the city as this is located in the basement of a building. I was quickly greeted and seated as I walked down the stairs. I got their Bean Crud Ox Tail Clay Pot, Snow Pea Sprouts, and the Salt and Pepper Chicken Wings. The Ox Tail Clay Pot was very good and flavorful with a lot of meat. The Snow Pea Sprouts tasted a bit old as it was a bit hard. The Chicken Wings were very standard and were not to greasy. The service was very fast on a weekend as we went late in the afternoon. Overall not a bad place to eat in Chinatown as the people working here are nice and attentive. I will return later to try other items on their menu, possibly the crab as it is recommended by many people.
author: Peter C.

description:
As others have pointed out, if you're looking for ambience, you're out of luck. This restaurant is in a basement. It's also the best damn Chinese food you will ever eat in a basement. The service is always fast and no-nonsense and the locals in Chinatown obviously eat here as well. The hot tea is great and I've never gone wrong ordering my two favorites; curry chicken and Mongolian beef. The portions are HUGE and for $5.50 at lunch you will be walking away full and with money still in your wallet.

I took a friend here for lunch one day and he asked for a straw for his drink. I didn't realize it until the waiter dashed up the steps to the street and returned a few minutes later, but they actually went out right then and bought some straws. I'll take that kind of service over some silk tapestries and fake ambience any day. 

Be warned, depending on where you sit, you may not get cell phone coverage in the restaurant. But hey, it's a basement!
author: Nick Z.

description:
We came here for our New Year's eve dinner! Pretty packed. This place has been here for years..........I remember coming here with my grandparents.

Yeah.......It's a dive and not the kind of place to come to if you are looking for fancy tablecloths and a quiet ambiance........It's not the place. It's pretty typical of most "authentic" places in Chinatown. 
  
Its a family business and lots of locals favorite this place.  The family is pretty friendly. 

We got the $38 dollar family special. It comes with garlic/pepper crab, beef claypot, Bok Choy vegitables, peking spare ribs, and egg flower soup.  

Love This place and We'll be back!
author: Tiki L.

description: Phenomenal place. 30 years later and it's still the best value in Chinatown. Yummy combo meal with sweet and sour pork, fried rice, almond chicken and wonton soup for $11. And the best I've ever had.
author: Smith S.

description:
tl;dr: Could be a decent place for a cheap lunar new year dinner. Not many people come here. 

This place has the potential to be better. They are easy to miss because their restaurant is down a stairwell and next to a really popular and more established hunan restaurant. The food is definitely MUCH cheaper than its neighbor. 

When my friend and I daringly ventured down this mysterious stairwell, we were expecting a much scarier basement but instead found a dingy, small space with about 10 wooden round and square tables. 
Despite its small space, it was not packed. A few people here and there were enjoying their meals. We got to sit in front of the kitchen entrance at a large round table that could seat 10 people. One of the workers was slicing bitter melons in front of us with a butcher knife as we were eating... I'll admit it was disturbing yet strangely charming(is that the right word?).

The food was not bad. Hints of Americanized dish components but still very affordably authentic.
author: Judge F.

description:
When the legendary restaurant "Sam Wo's" closed down in 2013, I was heartbroken to say the least. Afterwards, I was in desperate search of an authentic, great-tasting, and comfortable Chinese restaurant. Much to my surprise, I found it right across the street at Kam Lok. 

I ordered the Peking Duck. There's too many words to try and describe the food and experience I had so I'll say one...heavenly. Everyone should come and have this food, they see I'll not be let down.
author: Nicolas P.

description:
Four stars because it's pretty decent good food for such affordable prices.

For a full on lunch complete with rice, soup, and tea, you pay just $6.00 with tax. The downside is that if you're trying to go vegetarian, don't count on the appetizer soup being veggie friendly. I did not see meat in my soup, just veggie, but I tasted a bit of meat and the broth was oily. I should have known better, but I'm not too picky in my attempt to pursue a vegetarian diet. Their eggplant is good though. I went around 1:45pm and they weren't too busy. They were attentive and nice. 

I went here for dinner once too. They have a vegetarian special. For about $11/person, you get a place of eggplant, plate of string beans, plate of fried rice, vegetarian soup, and eggrolls. It was a lot of food. It does not look all that fancy, but it was good. It was on the greasy side but the deliciousness made up for it. $24 for dinner with tax. Not bad for two people and a lot of food. 

What I like about this place is that they don't try too hard to impress their customers. Heck, bring me my food, I will pay you the money, and we're good. Food's pretty legit for its price. Can't complain. 

I know people think the bathroom is gross. But eh, it's a San Francisco Chinatown bathroom and bathrooms in Chinatown are already hard to come by. I'm glad they have one at all.
author: Elle L.

description:
It's taken almost a year for me to post this review, but the facts remain the same.

Food = 3 to 3.5 stars
Service = 0
Value 3.5
Overall = 2 stars. But based on service, I would not come back.

Decent food, but really shitty service for our table of 12  (8 adults and 4 children). Some our group wanted a change from Chung King, so we decided come here instead. 

It was around 5:30 pm and not very busy yet. Since we did NOT reserve a large table, they asked us to wait while they converted a medium table to large. The "boss lady" was pretty rude from the get go! Her son was running around the restaurant from table to table including playing with the utensils/chopshicks. When we were seated they DID NOT give us the menu UNTIL we asked 5 minutes later. We decided to order a set dinner plus several more sides - getting their attention was really hard.

As soup came our she nearly screamed "MOVE, IT'S HOT". 

We asked for rice and she had to reiterate that it's $1 per person 3 times. I KNOW, just give us rice already...jesus christ. 

When they forgot one dish, we asked near the end of the meal and her reply was "how would I know"...WTF - really, that is your answer?!? 

When we left, the place was full with mainly party of 2 or 4s. The bitch, I mean boss lady, was so polite and nice to others while totally not caring about us. 

The only time I ever left a 10% tip.
author: Peter L.

description:
if we're talking about food, this place is pretty authentic...everything really has that "wok hei" (as my mother would say) and prices that don't make your wallet cry. my mom loves coming here even though the place is dirty and the staff is rude, but honestly, its a chinese restaurant what else would you expect in Chinatown. We always get three dishes which comes with a soup of the day. Love watching the old chinese guys bring in personals of hennessey and getting crunk. Loud kinda obnoxious atmosphere, but if you don't mind its awesome! When I gather enough people I'm definitely coming back for that $38 dinner deal.. a variety of dishes with soup.........AND IT COMES WITH sauteed LOBSTER.  



like seriously? how awesome is that?
author: Michelle G.

description:
After our club meetings, we often get together and come here.....

This is one of those chinese home style dishes restaurant ....all I have ever seen are chinese patrons.....

This is in the basement, hole in the wall type but always booked....and there is a reason....the food is yummy.....

If you ever miss your mom's home cooking, this is the place.....
author: Leslie Y.

description: Not only Yelpers but also local people recommended this place to us and it didn't disappoint me. The $18 for 3 dishes deal is fantastic. We could pick up any 3 dishes from a variety menu and it truly satisfied our craving of SF seafood. Free rice, soup and tea came along as well. I have nothing to complain and would definitely come back.
author: Cecille C.

description: Great place for family dinner. The best time to go is between Monday-Thursday when it's not that busy. The cook will have more time cooking your food rather than being rushed from other orders that he have to make. The portions are great size to have family style to share. Been here many times and I still enjoy their food. The only down fall is that sometimes the food is being rushed, it doesn't taste as good it suppose to taste when it's not being rushed.
author: Nick F.

description: Poor service and food takes forever! Place was empty when we arrived. Waited 15 mins for server to take our order then waited another 45 mins for food to come. Utensils were dirty, had rice and sauce stuck on plate and fork. Food is bland. Waitress demanded a 20% tip. Literally she chased us up the stairs to give her more money. This place was not worth the time or money.
author: Tanechka A.

description:
I found this hole in the wall place a year and a half ago and have been coming back every so often for its food. 

This place is definitely cheap/affordable for its decent Chinese food. I have to say that this is one of the better inexpensive Chinese restaurants around Chinatown that actually serves tasty Chinese dishes. My favorite dishes are the beef with chinese broccoli, chicken with string beans, pea sprouts, and the sweet & sour pork!! They do take-out as well!

Don't get fooled by the look of the outside! Even though it's a small basement restaurant place there are actually a lot of business here! One con though- the bathroom is not the cleaniest, but it's Chinatown after all.
author: Shanna C.

description: I have been coming to this restaurant since 1975. On my first visits, this little restaurant still had the original 1930s style private wooden booths. It was right out of a Charley Chan film. It has been remodeled at least 3 times since then... but the food is still authentic, amazing and truly like being in Taiwan. The won tons are still hand made and all food is prepared with old family recipes. You won't regret a visit if you want authenticity. This is where Chinese residents eat.
author: R. A.

description:
Came here prior to starting a bar crawl with some friends, we chose it at random because we liked the air of mystery a basement restaurant held.. well it turned out to not be very mysterious - but maybe that is a good thing when it comes to Chinese food! 

The restaurant is VERY casual, nothing fancy about Kam Lok. It is (as stated) in a basement, the walls are pink, the wait staff appeared to be family members of the owners, their children were running about the restaurant like wild things.
The service is quick and polite, our waitress did not speak the best English but we all managed to understand each other just fine.

The main attraction is of course the food. It is EXCELLENT! The prices can't be beat, and the serving sizes are huge!
Our friends ordered the Mongolian Beef to share- it was delicious, perfectly cooked, a bit spicy with a mountain of rice on the side.
I sadly cannot remember the name of the dish I ordered, but it was a stir fried/sauteed eggplant dish with other veggies likewise served with a heaping mound of white rice. MY GOD this eggplant was good, there was enough of it to feed three people!
My fiance ordered a shrimp noodle pot - also delicious with perfectly cooked shrimp and super flavor-full glass noodles. (I stole more than a few bites!)

If you are in China Town and are at a loss for where to go eat, try Kam Lok Restaurant. Great food, great prices, interesting if slightly divey atmosphere. Plus it is right by the Li Po Cocktail Lounge for some post dinner drinks!
author: Allie H.

description:
This is one of the best HOLE IN THE WALL joints in SF! (for chinese)
and it literally is a hole in the wall because you would NEVER think that an underground basement chinese restaurant would be THIS good!

I can almost suggest anything here no matter if you're a local visiting chinatown or a tourist visiting the city. 

DONT be fooled by those ladies handing out flyers and pamphlets of some local dimsum restaurants. They're obviously there to try and lure you to their dim sum restaurant because they aren't getting much traffic, better yet, you should hit up this spot downstairs on the middle of Washington st! 

I can def recommend their prawns and egg foo young, it's def one of the best. 
I like almost anything they have there, I just wish they were bigger
author: Kenny L.

description:
This joint used to be good comfort food place, can't say that's the case anymore.  

I was looking for fried small fish (white rice fish in Chinese) and surprisingly no luck.  Just when we gave up and hubby suggested to just eat here since we haven't visited for a while...I see it on one of the paper menus on the wall *smile*.  Not just fried but salt & pepper too!

The place is cleaner, new coat of paint at least. There is now a tv in there playing Chinese soap.  It was a little over half full?  There were a few large round tables with families celebrating birthday?

We had to flag the lady owner down to order and waited a very long time for our food, which I find a bit annoying since what we ordered shouldn't take a long time and they weren't that busy.

What we had:
the salt & pepper fried little fish - $8.50? - this came first.  Too much batter.  I had the first two w/ it and had to peel off what I can for the rest.

war wonton - it's basically combo wonton - $6.50 - very disappointed.  the portion is small.  there were less wonton than expected and the wonton itself was small and not much flavor.  the combo was 2 shrimp, a few slices of calamari, bbq pork some slices of Italian http://static1.px.yelpcdn.com/static/20100218/i/ico/star_big_2.gifsquash, carrot and snap peas.  blah.  even with spoons of hot sauce, it was still blah.

bitter melon beef over pan fried noodles - noodles were too fried, almost all fried (similar to Vietnamese style).  too much corn starch in the sauce.  instead of savory, it was sweet - too much sugar.  

There are better places in Chinatown, yes even cheaper.
author: Gloria H.

description:
Seafood is fresh, crabs lobster and fish pulled straight from the tank. Crabs looked delicious. This is a place for the local Chinese community. The portions are substantial and the menu is very extensive. 
Will try additional items on next visit. Took our Grandchildren and they had a great time waiting the chef "Catch the Fish and Crabs in the tank. Prices were extremely affordable. 
Dining area is noisy from all the family conversations occurring throughout the restaurant. 

THe dining area is down stairs and not easily accessed for disabled people.
author: Bruce H.

description: You can get a whole lot of food for under $40 here. They have two dinner sets to choose from that include five different dishes for only $38. One set has baked crab, and the other has lobster. The food is also quite good. The service is very good for a Chinese Restaurant. The place may look crummy, but you can't complain. The food is cheap and delicious. What more can you ask for?
author: Jackie B.

description: Love this weird place! The food is always good.  Today we had amazing honey walnut prawns.
author: Lisa B.

description:
The only bad thing about this place is that the bathroom doesn't feel too clean, but it's way better than most Chinatown joints across the world. 

Apart from that, though, Kam Lok was the first place we stopped by for lunch in our visit to SF. We got 3 dishes (two seafood and one veggie) for $18 from the Chinese only menu.  Free rice, soup du jour, and tea came along with it.  Service was good, too.  The food was a bit oily, but overall, delish and fresh!  I recommend Kam Lok for visitors and locals.
author: Geraldine K.

description: Took one hour for our food and it's not fully cooked!
author: James Z.

description:
When you don't feel like paying 10 to 13 dollar for an order of chow fun, chow mein, or a beef tofu over rice at those Chinese fufu restaurants, you need to come here. 

This was how we ate growing up in Chinatown and, believe me, it was a treat. No bells and whistles, just fast, friendly, inexpensive food. You don't come here for the ambiance because for God's sake you are in a basement. It is a hole in a wall under the heart of San Francisco's Chinatown. 

5.50 for most of the dishes I ordered.

Curry Chicken over rice...........I love Chinese curry....but HRD makes it better and they are not even in Chinatown.

Tomato beef chow mein...........It's ok..........it probably needs to be a little more tangy.

Chinese broccoli and chicken over rice.......I liked it. fresh vegetables, great Chinese brown slurry.

The total price was 16.50.............yes, this includes tax.
author: jason g.

description: I love hole in the wall Chinese but I really didn't care for this one. Service was really bad - I know that's part of hole in the wall Chinese but this one was worse than normal.  Food usually overcomes that issue, but not here. The generals chicken was the worst I've had.  Definitely some questionable chicken parts. The shrimp fried rice was ok and veggie egg rolls were the best part. I think it may have been too authentic for me.
author: Bobby H.

description:
Best hole-in-the-wall noodle soups, congee, and crispy roast pork!

Came here with my parents, siblings, and grandmother - all of us descended from robust Cantonese stock, with an equally robust appetite for legitimate Cantonese cuisine and a proud family history in the restaurant business. 

Closing her eyes and smiling as she sat down at the table, my mom described this restaurant as the one restaurant in SF Chinatown that "really felt like home."

Worth a visit!
author: Jenn W.

description: Easily the worst Chinese food I've had in my life. Went in there during lunch break to have some authentic Chinese food... Well as it turns out "Chinese family cuisine" stands for: no spices whatsoever an barely any chicken in a meat dish...  Just go somewhere else, there are so many good restaurants around.
author: Wolf F.

description: You have to walk down the stairs to get to the restaurant. Solid family style dinners and good food. It's pretty clean even though it's on the basement level. We used to come here often for dinner when we lived nearby.
author: Jennifer T.

description: I give them 3.5 stars. I never even knew about this place until we had a work dinner here. We ordered the mystery set dinner that's written all in Chinese. We got clams, steamed catfish (we substituted didnt feel like crab), the good soup and the free soup too, fried chicken wings, vegetables, fried fish. I thought all was very good, some of my coworkers complained it was a bit salty. I've had over salted disgusting food before and it didn't taste like that to me. My favorite was fried chicken wings, clams in black bean sauce and fried fish. They sure can make good fried food!
author: Karen T.

description:
Craving some chow fun, I asked Mary C. for some suggestions in Chinatown since I was headed that way.  One of the first places she thought of was Kam Lok on Washington Street.  

I wanted an order of vegetarian chow fun, dry style.  This time, my mom told me to request it by saying "jop choy," so they would know it's really vegetarian.  Well, thank goodness I did!  It came loaded with greens - bok choy, zucchini, another Chinese green, onions, and a few carrots.  (The last time I ordered vegetarian chow fun at another place, all I got were bean sprouts and onions!  Blah!  What kind of vegetarian is that?! http://www.yelp.com/biz/gBfPyzPRmeOaj3SdcIj0Rw#hrid:IeZ7_IKye5xsdIzPA9G8VA/query:sushi)  The order cost me $6.00, which was actually cheaper than the other place too!

I called in the order so it was ready to go by the time I showed up.  Kam Lok can easily be missed because it's a restaurant on the basement level, so you have to walk down some stairs.  

I also requested some hot chili oil and she gave me one container. I asked for another, and realized that I should have gotten more.  I love hot chili oil! Yum!  

Overall, pretty greasy stuff - it's chow fun after all! It satisfied my craving for chow fun AND I got my veggies in! 

Sidenote: They have a a bunch of lunch specials that are $5.50 and served with rice.  They also have a bunch of menus written in Chinese, so try to go with someone who can read the language or at least speak Cantonese.
author: Teri C.

description:
This place was a pleasant surprise the first time we came here. We got the
-duck with taro
-spinach with egg three ways
-clay pot eggplant

The spinach dish was absolutely delicious, and we've adopted our own version that we make all the time now! I highly recommend coming here for a quick meal that is affordable, light in flavor, and tasty. The owner made some great recommendations.

The only caveat is their menu seems to fluctuate a lot depending on what vegetables are in season, and the quality of food seems to depend on the day (I came here another time and it wasn't as good as I remembered).
author: Ellen T.

description:
took a walk over from home for a late lunch. chose this place on the strength of yelp reviews. to those of you who rave about this place: are you serious? I had the potstickers, salt and pepper fried tofu, Mongolian beef, white rice and tea. 

to the indifferent, surly owner/waiter: I'm sorry that you had to get up out of your chair to take our order. I know it's annoying when you have to stop doing nothing.

to the other waitresses/family members that kept up a super loud conversation throughout the meal: I apologize for trying to enjoy a meal and spending my money at your restaurant.

to the health department: are you sure the 75 rating is correct and not 65?

to the kitchen: how can the food get cold when it is walked over from 15 feet away? also how do you manage to make the potsticker's dough so thick and underdone? 

on the plus side, the tea was almost hot.

there's something magical about eating in a restaurant that is permeated with pride... no magic here.
author: Sanil S.

description:
not the best chinese food i've had

got the house special noodles which was basically chow mein and then the brocolli/mustard greens which weren't really seasoned or flavored

we asked for our food spicy and it was but the flavor wasn't really there

went in because when my friends and i walked by it looked like a hole in the wall. it was full of people and so we figured it must be good...but it wasnt
author: Hemesh P.

description:
This place is a total hole in the wall

To get to it you have to descend a flight of stairs into a basement, the decor and ambiance is functional not artful.

The outstanding feature of this place is the food!  The price to goodness ratio is awesome! you can get a 6 dish prefix dinner including crab for $70 bucks!  I went there with 9 people, we ordered that and we had TOO much food, and everything was sooo good!

Granted half of our crew were genetically blessed (I.E HOT) petite Asian girls who eat small amounts, but the rest of us are growing guys who can do serious damage.  

This is NOT a place to bring a first date, your not going to score any brownie points with the ladies here... unless your a broke-ass college student and your date is in the same boat, but even then, its iffy at best... go somewhere else if you want to impress a lady.

It is a Chinese greasy spoon, the kind of place you want to wipe down your tea cups and utensils before using them.  It helps big time if you or somebody in your group speaks Chinese, but if you don't, you can get by.  The staff speaks broken Chinglish.

Service is pretty standard for these kind of places, just the bare minimum, the take the order and bring you the food... they don't check back on you, and you may need to wave your hands in the air to get a new pot of tea.  If that doesn't work just walk to the old man watching the really small TV and ask him.

This is an Awesome place to go if your an established couple, or to bring a group of friends who are into good food, at a cheap price.

For the single guy looking for hotness... your not going to find it here.  Its not near any bars or clubs, they don't stay open that late.  Your more likely to see old Fobby Chinese families eating here.

My five stars is based solely on the food, and thats what you should go for, NOT the service NOT the atmosphere just cheap awesome grub...
author: Aaron R.

description: This place was a great find! It can be really easy to miss as its storefront is just an a door with stairs leading to a basement. Order one of the dinner specials. For $11/person, you will have a very delicious feast.
author: Andrew H.

description:
five minutes after ordering we discovered that instead of being a party of 7, we were actually a party of 8. There was a cockroach under my sister's chair. not a dead cockroach, a wriggling, squirming, very large cockroach. we should have got up and left right then but my stupid family is too polite.

Worst Chinese food that I have ever had. 

hot and sour soup: so spicy it overwhelmed any hint of flavor

sweet and sour chicken: gelatinous, gloopy sauce smothering burnt low-quality chicken. yum!
 
cashew chicken: this chicken was basically raw, and halfway through our meal the waitress gestured to it with a pained expression and sent someone else over to ask if it was "ok". pretty sure they messed this one up and were checking to make sure we didn't notice. 

eggplant and salted fish: just a bowl of cat barf, really. 

salt and pepper tofu: this one was actually ok, 1 out of 7 ain't bad!

fried green beans: usually my favorite dish, but these were totally flavorless. I have no idea how they turned something so delicious into something so bad.

pan fried noodles with pork: the pork was completely inedible. I'm not even sure it WAS pork. 

besides this, the tea was burned, the service was poor, the atmosphere was loud, chaotic and cramped, and when we left a four year old behind the counter accused us of not paying our bill. it was sitting right there (with a tip!) on the table. good lord.
author: Ariel M.

description:
3.5 stars, and since I have a cold, I'm not feeling extremely charitable.  It has the potential to be 4 stars.

My friend (the one who liked Great Hunan) and I were on a quest for a set of Chinese Chess.  He's a big tall white guy who sits in Chinatown on his lunch break and watches old Chinese men play that game with fascination.  Today, he asked me where he could buy that game, so we wandered around, asked a few places, and finally found a set that was to his liking.  We got hungry, so I suggested a place that neither of us had tried before.  My rationale for doing that is to a) try new places, and b) not get blamed for a bad place.

We ended up at Kam Lok, and upon surveying the menu outside, we walked down the steps into the little basement (how do these places pass inspection for being handicap-accessible??).  We were seated right away, and the other people in the restaurant were mostly families, including one with two small children who seemed very interested in watching us eat.

Relatively clean for being a Chinese basement place, and the prices are relatively good.  They have lunch specials that come with rice, and they range from about $5 to $7.  Braised tofu, sweet & sour pork, broccoli beef, etc.

I decided on prawn won ton soup ($6), after being too overwhelmed with the other choices of won ton soup (chicken, wor won ton, beef, pork, supreme broth, what?).  It came with about 6 (that's it?!) won tons (pork and a bit of shrimp), and about 6 cooked shrimp.  The broth was hot, flavorful and slightly spicy, since I'd asked for it that way.  The soup also had bok choy.

My friend ordered the sweet & sour pork ($5.50) and it was a really big plate of white rice, with pork and bell peppers sauteed in sweet & sour sauce.  Good price for the portion, but since I'm not a fan of the sweet & sour, I didn't get to taste any.  He seemed to definitely like it though.

Bill came to $12.40 with tax.  Definitely worth it if you're looking for a cheap, slightly above average Chinese meal.
author: Tori S.

description:
Came here with a bunch of coworkers for lunch.  This is sorta of dive-y place (it's located in a basement).  Food is ridiculously cheap though.

We ordered the $38 set menu.  We got:

Beef Soup - beef was a little too chewy for my taste
Salt & Pepper Chicken wings - this was really good
Soy Sauce Tofu w/ Veggies - The tofu was nice and soft
Sa Cha Beef - This was yummy too
Crab - Crab was very fresh and there was a lot to go around
Golden Spinich - Eh, I don't like how they put salted eggs on the spinich.  Totally ruined it for me but I guess if you like it it's ok.

They charge $1/person for rice.  So if you want to avoid the rice charge, order a rice plate.

Service was kinda slow which was surprising because they weren't that busy!

Lunch came down to $12/person.  Not expensive but not that cheap either.  It's an ok place.
author: Wendy H.

description:
Reading the other reviews for Kam Lok reminds me why I don't trust Yelp for ethnic restaurants.

Kam Lok is classic Canton-style Cantonese food (as opposed to HK style); the kind I grew up eating.  Ordering hot and sour soup or mongolian beef at a restaurant like this is, well, what can I say?

For what it is, a local neighborhood restaurant in Chinatown, Kam Lok rates five stars for food.  For ambiance, this restaurant is a classic.  I ate here growing up as did my father. There is a reason why locals only eat here and it boils down to one thing: wok aroma (wok hei) or the flavor unique to Cantonese food produced by a well seasoned wok, a high-quality high-fire cooking oil, intense heat, and a skilled chef.

Newer Hong Kong style restaurants often lack wok hei and wok hei is hard to produce in a home kitchen without a professional wok burner.  Furthermore as restaurants change hands and the older generation of wok chefs retire, fewer and fewer restaurants are able to produce food with the right flavor. These days, family-run restaurants with an experienced hand in the kitchen like Kam Lok are few and far between.

Order the Cantonese home-style classics:  mustard green soup, steamed whole fish, fresh garlic fried vegetables, dry fried rice noodles with beef, etc. and you are in for a treat.  When the last two dishes arrive, inhale before tucking in; that heavenly aroma is "wok hei."
author: Craig Y.

description:
Wandering around Chinatown on a rainy Friday, we happened onto Kamlok.  It's just the kind of hole-in-the- er, ground - that we were looking for.  We may not have ordered the specialties of the house, but it was very satisfying.  As I recall, we had Szechwan tofu, chinese broccoli and maybe vegetable with garlic sauce, I can't remember now.  What I do remember was that it was a bit cold and dank, and that there were lots of guys down there drinking snifters of brandy with their lunches/snacks. 

The food was great - just simple and straightforward - and the service was the same.  I would go back here anytime if I was in the area.  But I'd try to go back with someone who knew the place or the cuisine better, just to get a little more out of the visit.
author: Modibo S.

description: Seafood pan-fried noodle for $6.99 was off the hook. Gotta try it. Black bean sauce beef chow-fun was great too for $5.99. The food is great and cheap. You will never walk into this restaurant unless you were searching for it, as it is a basement. Give it a try, everything on the lunch special is around $5-$7. Dinner is relatively cheap too. Large portions too. Oh, don't whine about the service, it is not bad service, you get your food and tea, basic Chinese restaurant service.  Go for the food, that's what matters, right? Oh please don't try pot stickers and egg rolls and complain about how bad it is. All westerners do is try the crap at Chinese restaurants and complain about it being crap. Most Chinese restaurant don't make them from scratch, and they will laugh at you for ordering this crap behind your back. You are better off buying some ling ling pot stickers from Costco.
author: Ken M.

description:
this is the first part of a 2 part lunch review:
My couz's uncle owns this place, and as a treat went to Chinatown and got us beef and broccoli & soup to bring over to my place so we could have dinner while watching True Blood & The Pacific (both on HBO & both great shows). 
Beef & Broccoli was really good (and im not a veggie eater) big pieces of beef and they were nice an tender, and the broccoli was steamed to perfection.
Haven't tried the soup yet and my Couz cant remember the name of it, but the soup is black and it has things that look like seaweed floating in it, the only drawback is that it has tofu in it, but looks intriguing so im gonna try it anyway.
author: timothy h.

description: My dad and I stayed in San Francisco for a week, and we were trying to find some good food at a reasonable price. We went to other restaurants before we found here, but it didn't went so well. My dad somehow picked this hole. I consider that was luck. The place doesn't look decent if you compare to all other restaurant in the states. However, I'm from hong kong, this place is acceptable to me. The food tastes excellent. The price is great! I will recommend here.
author: Chris L.

description: It's always a good sign when 90% of the patrons in a Chinese restaurant are actually Chinese! We got the $38 set menu meal with lobster and the 4 of us were stuffed. Good food, excellent price!
author: M C.

description:
My sis and I were wandering around Chinatown trying to find a menu with vegetarian options. We had been searching for blocks now. Fading fast, we came across their menu and without a word, climbed down the stairs to the little basement restaurant.

The place itself looks a little run down. The tile floor was falling apart, but it didn't seem dirty. A nice gentlemen sat us down and brought us tea right away. 

They let us order off the lunch menu but we still could have split one order of Szechuan tofu. It was spicy but delicious. The spring rolls were nice and crispy and the tea was lovely. And everything was supercheap! Overall, a nice little dinner, but nothing fancy.
author: Kelly C.

description:
Found this little hole in the wall by accident in 2004. We were literally ushered down the stairs by a woman who was distributing flyers while we were walking by. We sure were glad she did! The meal was cheap (like $30 for 5 dishes, including a crab dish - enough to feed 6 ppl) and it was really good!

Fast-forward to 2010, and here we are again. This time it was only the 2 of us, so we did not get the sets that they have. We ordered some salt and pepper chicken wings for appetizers -- the batter was flavorful and the wings were CRISPY! For entrées, we got the clay pot tofu with chicken & salted fish and ginger & scallion oysters. The tofu was DELISH!!! It was one of the best I've tasted and I order that dish all the time. The oysters were decent but a tad too greasy for our taste. Oh, they included free soup-of-the-day too. And the total came out to ~$20, that's cheap!!
author: JuneLim L.

description: Complete hole in the wall. Prices Are dirt cheap, food is decent-good . The staff if you can call them that were mediocre at best. Basically if you want cheap good food and don't mind the waitress treating you like her first born and only daughter go.
author: Rick A.

description:
You wanna talk about cheap?  This is cheap!!!  At Kam Lok, you can get a set menu fit for 10 people that consists of the following: soup du jour, steamed chicken with wood ear fungus and mushrooms, stir-fried bittermelon with beef, black bean steamed catfish and tofu, salt and pepper pork chops, tender greens, honey walnut prawns, egg and tomato beef, all for $100 (tax and tip included)!

Located underground, I would have never considered giving Kam Lok a chance.  But were it not for my father's involvement with a certain "benevolent association" (or what my cousins and I like to call, a "Chinatown triad") that are a dime a dozen in Chinatown, I reluctantly came here for a celebratory lunch with a bunch of Chinatown old fogies.  But much to my surprise, I was duly impressed.

The portions are humongous, the food is served piping hot and lightning fast, and most importantly, the food was good!  There is nothing fancy about this place, it's a hole-in-the-wall (or, would it be more appropriate to say hole-in-the-underground?) and they serve up some extremely down-to-earth Chinese homecooking.
author: Diane L.

description: After the CNY parade we stopped in here (a little hidden underground) for dinner. Busy night for them since there was a tourgroup in there too. The food was good (of what I could eat, cause I'm a vegetarian) & the service was ok, but it was very busy. Everything came out pretty fast and hot. Not sure how the price is and the bathroom was decently clean. Would come back here again with my family.
author: Irene L.

description: Kam Lok is a hole in the basement chinese restaurant located right across from yucky Sam Woo except that it is 10x better. Just order the salt and pepper crab ($17) and Singapore rice noodle ($7) and your taste buds and wallet will thank you. Another big star for taking credit cards and waving good bye thank you when we left.  I will be back for more!
author: Lisa Z.

description: Walking around china town we decided to check this place out .this place is pretty cool because it's underground basement type restaurant but that's where the coolness stops .... The service is bad ... The lady who served us was very unhappy  and gave us the menus and walked away after a while she came back and asked for our order , so even though they advertise dim sum ...THEY DO NOT HAVE DIM SUM so instead I ordered beef won ton soup and my family ordered pork chow mein and beef with oyster sauce and rice well the rice didn't come out until we were halfways done eating and even though we had asked her twice , once when she had got done talking to friends she finally brought out the rice and the rest of the food had no flavor and was bland especially the soup . If the service doesn't keep me away from this place then the food def will . There are plenty of good Chinese food restaurants in china town and this not one of them
author: christina a.

description: After walking around SF during Chinese New Year, stopped by this restaurant for dinner. It's not particularly big and is underground, sort of. You'll have to go down stairs and voila, the sitting area appears! We ate family style so I got to try a lot of things, a lot of which I can't recall their names. There was Beef broccoli, a mushroom dish, fried flounder and a few others. Everything was really good and the vegetables were fresh. For Chinese food it was very flavorful and surprisingly inexpensive.
author: Shawn S.

description:
Talk about embarrassing. There's a couple places you have to hit up when you take visitors around San Francisco for the first time. One of them is Chinatown. Granted, I don't frequent Chinatown too much if not at all I would expect all the restaurants to deliver when it comes to food.

So on a quick romp through C-town and avoiding many a flyer thrown at you by a host of one restaurant or another, we landed in Kam Lok... and I still have no clue as to how exactly we got there. Located in a basement, not a roasted duck hanging in the window, and the servers were sleeping on the tables! Awesome, oh and embarrassing. Luckily we were starving and tired so it was pretty much an eat and go experience. The food came out fairly quick. Bland won ton soup, generic pork fried rice, rubbery salt and pepper squid, greasy fried flounder, top that off w/the poorest service (how is that possible when you're the only customers in the joint!) and you've got a terrible experience at Kam Lok. I know next time to drive straight through C-town, check out the pretty lights and the overflowed markets, and over to Sunset for authentic Chinese food.
author: Cecile Q.

description:
FOR EVERYONE WHO HASNT BEEN HERE FOR THE PAST YEAR:

The restaurant switched owners and chefs. Ever since the new crew that came in (family runned), the food service and cleanliness increased tremendously.

New plates, cups, chopsticks and everything is very clean even though it is located in a basement. My whole family love this places, not because only of the food but also the prices too. 

Like the lady that stands outside says : good food, good price. She isnt lying.

If you aren't looking for exotic dishes, then ordering from the 3 for 18 menu where you choose 3 dishes for 18 dollars. we always order 6 or so. 

My family and I always come here to eat because of the friendly service, good food and cheap prices. Please dont be discouraged because of the location or the kids running around. The staff here are a family and I guess they spend most of their time in the restaurant to help run it. Family runned restaurants are usually better because they put in all their effort to make it good.

COME TRY THIS PLACE ITS DELICIOUS.... ( I always go for the eggplant claypot when I come home from school every break/holiday even though i love all their other dishes)
author: Bonnie Z.

description:
This is really cheap and you get alot!

For Cantonese Chinese family style, this should be on your list. Not white table cloths, but great for friends and family. Be careful walking down the stairs and you will see several round tables that will seat 8 persons. We had House Soup, Steamed Black Bean Sauce Cat Fish on Tofu, Snow Pea Shrimp, White Rice, Beef Gai Laan, Chopped vegetables w/Lettuce Cups.
author: GARY C.

description:
Very slow, erratic service. The wait staff are not assigned tables to take care of, so everything is chaos, everyone helping all and no one. 

First time in my life I have encountered fake bbq pork. I got a cha-sui tong mean which is pretty standard fare in this sort of HK style diner, but it was awful. Overcooked noodles, weird pressed fake pork, and no red vinegar on hand. 

Our party also got: 
spicy eggplant: edible
dry green beans: decent
oxtail hot pot: inedible
lemon chicken: tasty, but sickening after a bite

Truthfully, it was all sickening. It seemed promising when we walked in and there were lots of Chinese people speaking Chinese here. But the food was terrible. It wasn't that it was so dirty or revolting. It was just unappetizing or lacking taste and way way overcompensated with oil. Then the service or lack thereof makes it restaurant hell.
author: Allisoto P.

description: I ate dinner here with 4 other people Christmas night after watching a movie at the nearest Metreon. We ordered 5 vegetarian plates with drinks, the bill was $80.  The food was decent.  The Tsingtao beer was tasteful, very Chinese.  I enjoyed it, but not a 5 star restaurant.  Kam Lok is good for late night goers or family dinners.  Wasn't expecting it to be elegant, so the food that was delivered was acceptable.  I am sure the main dishes are good too.
author: Bryant K.

description:
*sigh*

Good-bye Kam Lok, thanks for the memories.

Rewind back to 1995. I was younger, dumber, more vibrant and felt I had to be anywhere but home. Because of this, I used to allways end up in San Francisco whether it be at Noon or 1am. .....Over the next 13 years, I grew older, smarter, moved, and my trips to SF and being out in SF at Noon, let alone 1am became less frequent.

The one thing which remained consistent was Kam Lok. The food, the sorta nasty but kinda tasty free house soup they give you, the fact that the lady owner always remembered my order, the execuation of my dish was always consistent, always fresh......I moved to Oakland and always wondered why many places in Oakland could not get my dish the same way KamLok did. Why the Vegs were always so fresh, every single time.

In the past 5 years, I would probably make it to KamLok once per year. 
Each time, the lady knew what I wanted....

So last night, I happened to be in SF at 9pm and had to go to Kam Lok. Parking after 8pm in Chinatown is never an issue.  I walk in and the lady owner remembers me and says " today last day", and without a pause, recites my favorite dish by memory.

So goodbye KamLok and thanks for the memories, the great meals and always remembering my favorite dish for 13 years.

*sigh*
author: Garfield J.

description:
Who goes into a basement in Chinatown?  After all the warnings from the chinatown firefighters, I have to be crazy.  

Well, overcome your fear if you want one of the best deals ever.  

Look and Feel:  honestly, it's not as shady as a lot of places and the staff makes an effort to keep things tidy. Going AFTER the dinner rush meant unbussed tables everywhere.  The chairs and tables do match, and it is relatively okay for a place in Chinatown.  

Service:   the wait staff is awesome, be nice and they will be nicer.  However, the whole unbussed table thing was discouraging.  That could have been due to 2 guys working the floor when they needed 4.

Pricing:  great value for individual dishes and set menus.  Seriously, we ordered away with 3 hungry individuals and had a bill for less than $40.  And yes, this included rounds of beer (plural).  Ask them about specials and they will be happy to tell you.

Food:  pretty non-americanized, although my sweet and sour friend needed pot stickers and egg rolls.  So you COULD get that if necessary.  Should I as an ABC be ashamed to ask for them for that stuff?  Anyhow, if you get past that, there is great clay pot beef stew.  I recall ordering fish maw soup which was great.  Besides that I can't recall the other dish sticking out as good or bad.  

All this talk makes me want to go back...
