You could easily spend less than $10 a person, or spend just a bit more for a lot of food.
author: Simon Y.

description:
I read through the reviews and stuck to the Cantonese-style dishes. We had the sauteed flounder with veg (really just baby bok choi) and the sizzling beef. I thought the beef was a little bit rubbery, but my son who ordered it thought it was great. The fish was great.

I loved the atomsphere (in the basement and full of locals). Service was fast, but I thought the pot stickers were average at best. I'd come back again and try some other dishes.
author: Craig S.

description:
Good, solid Chinese food and A LOT of it. My friend and I ordered the combo dinner for two which came with a boatload of food and a good price. You won't go away hungry.

Just an average, run-of-the-mill authentic Chinese restaurant in the heart of chinatown. You could do MUCH worse. :)
author: Molly E.

description:
Wait! What's that smell??? It smells like duck, let's go check it out!

My mouth was watering and I was in need of some duck to sober me up. We were one of the last ones to be seated and the waiter seemed a little pushy, like he wanted to get us fed and out of there. No worries!

I ordered tea to help sober both myself and my female aquaintance up, and the the duck and noodles. It hit the spot. They were a little slow on the rice when we needed a refill but they kept our water glasses full...a HUGE plus!

The lady at the end was kinda pushy in getting us out..we were just lucky we got to have authentic chinese in Chinatown without getting Shanghai'ed!!!
author: Ryan K.

description:
Me and my fiance went searching for a nice inexpensive place to eat on a saturday in chinatown, and with so many different restaurants around, we didn't know where to go. Luckily, my uncle recommended this small place and we decided to check it out. 

Interesting place, you have to really be looking for it to find it as it is underground. There is a sign outside pointing down to where the restaurant is, but its not too noticeable. 

We went down the stairs into the place and were immediately seated by the waitress at a small table. There were not too many people there, but it seemed they are quite ready for larger crowds.

The menus were given to us and I have to say, I like the selection they have here. Normally when eating with the family we would order many dishes to share, but since this was just for the two of us, we decided on sweet and sour chicken and west lake beef soup. 

While waiting for our dishes, I looked around and noticed the decor. Not much to this place, mostly bare walls except for some advertisements on dishes, a large chinese character on the back wall, and a flat screen tv behind us showing a chinese tv station. The tables are fairly clean and simple, the chairs are a bit old, but as this is a cheaper budget restaurant, I can understand this.

The food came and we tried the soup. I am someone who LOVES good westlake beef soup, and this one was well pleasing. Prepared nicely, freat flavor, hint of sweetness, it was really good.
The sweet and sour was perfectly done, very tender chicken and the flavor was very nice. 

I have to say I really liked this place, the service was good, good food, and good price. Me and my fiance really enjoyed it and would return for sure.
author: Joshua Y.

description: Was initially discouraged by the basement location but was starving and HAD to get off the packed streets (flower fair) to take a break. Everything was delicious, the portions were huge and very fresh. Yes, kids were running around and there are tanks holding catfish and other 'creatures' when you walk in. It is very minimally furnished/decorated. But the service was friendly enough and genuine.
author: Dana H.

description:
It's not the cleanest place, it's in the basement, it looks a bit dingy. But if you want a quick bite like Rachel Ray's $40 a day, look no further. In fact, $38 bucks gets you 5 entrees 1) Live lobster 2)Braised Tofu 3)beef, egg drop soup 4)Mongolian beef 5)salt and pepper wings. All done just right. Yes, you read right, live lobster that's taken out of the tank there and then.

This is a Cantonese style place. As it is Cantonese, the "wok hei", or flavor-of-the-wok is the basic criteria for rating the food. This place has a lot of it. The food tastes Cantonese, light soup, stir fry with a lot of "wok hei" caramelization, and good ginger onion style seafood.

The $38 set meal is good for 4 people, or if you take it to go, it's good for two days! Take that Rachel Ray.
author: Vocal T.

description: My family usually go to different places for dinner.  We recently have been dining here for dinner.  The service isn't that bad, considering the fact that the owners know us.  The soups are usually pretty good.  I love the ginger and scallion chicken.  If I am watching my mom's shop, I sometimes come here for lunch.  They have a special lunch deal which is porridge/congee and noodles for about 4 bucks.  Decor-wise, it's not the best, and I agree with some of the comments about the restrooms.  The way I see it, it's the same cleanliness as other chinese restaurants in chinatown.  No surprise for me there.
author: Philip L.

description: Ok well i was wandering the streets for a place to eat after going fishing with my friends. I was walking to new king tin restaurant hoping for good food. But theres tihs woman who keeps yelling at the top of her lung GOOD FOOD GOOD DINNER. and it was really annoying and she kept dragging me into the restaurant. I ddecided to respect her decision since she was so into it and went in. At first i didnt even know there was a restaurnat there. It was all underground so i had to walk down the flight of stairs. I ordered a fried crab and a chow fan becuase they were on sale. My friends and i talked for like 15 mniutes before the rice came and after we got full then the crab came. I was really annoyed because it took so long. We ate the crab but the shell was really hard so we asked for a shell opener. But to my surprise, they didnt have any. I was so mad. We rapidly wrapped tihngs up . The check came out to be 67 bucks for nothing. I gave a 2 dollar tip and was out of there. Never going back to that place again.
author: Roger L.

description: the roast pork and bbq pork are good. there was something that looked like fabric of some type in the bbq pork that i had to pull out though :(
author: NY Y.

description:
I don't know why but I'm always attracted to those Chinese BBQ spots with the golden brown ducks hanging in the window, heads still intact,  and staring longingly at you as if to say "come in and eat me so I don't have to hang out here anymore." Kam Lok is great because they're open super late(3am) 7days a week I believe. When you're swilly and mobbing through chinatown at 2:30 in morning, after a long night at the Li Po, nothing is better than a roast suckling pig rice plate, or a pile of crispy salt & pepper squid *drool*. Top all with chili sauce & enjoy! It may not be the greatest Chinese meal you'll ever have but the portions are sizeable & for $5 it's damn fresh, damn fast and they got brew too...Woo hoo! What more can you ask of a Chinese diner?   make sure they give you the white "rice & noodle plate" menu and not the green one unless you're trying to come out the pocket a la carte stylee.

you WILL be satisfied!
author: NaN K.

description: I was just checking out their menu, and some lady kind of rushed us in. Good thing the prices weren't that bad. My friend ordered the lamb rice plate, while I got the house special chow fun. The food was okay, but a little too greasy for my liking. It was kind of nice having the place underground, but it kind of felt too "underground" if you know what I mean. The decorations and service were effortless and quite ghetto. They were bitching the whole time I was there because some guy left without paying. All I can say is, this is not what I was expecting. (It smelled like a hospital in China.)
author: Alex Y.

description:
For a family dinner, this is a pretty good place tucked in a basement hidden in Chinatown.  It has A LOT of items written in Chinese plastered all over the walls.  But some has pictures so you can tell what it is.  

They got excellent set dinner menus (NOT the BS stuff for tourists like egg rolls and sweet and sour pork!)  I mean they have set dinners like:  Ginger Lobster; Mongolian Beef; Stuffed Tofu; Mustard Greens; Minced Beef Soup...all for $28.

The food is good and I also checked the SF Sanitation score: 71.  Not bad for a basement joint.
author: Gary Y.

description: Cheap and good Chinese food.  This place does by any means have a nice ambiance but that doesn't matter because I'm there for the food.
author: Peter W.

description: This is a hole in the wall type of place, but the food is good and authentic,if you know how to order.  On weeknights, the place can be fairly packed with locals, which is a good sign.  You won't see lots of tourists here, and the ambiance is certainly not great.  The English menu is straightforward, but you get better dishes off the Chinese menu.  I'd rate it 4 stars for food, 3 stars for atmosphere; at times the owner's kids are running around like crazy; good for a laugh but could certainly annoy some who are not used to it.
author: Bentley L.

description: This place sucks. The women's bathroom smells like a dumpster because they store their garbage cans in there.  We waited 30 friggin minutes to even get our first o five dishes (soup).  Soup is already premade, why did it take them so long to scope into two bowls and bring it out?  Being asian, the rice needs to come out FIRST or maybe even second after the soup, so we can eat it with the other entrees.  It came out LAST after asking them several times to bring it out.   The food wasn't even that good.  I'll never go back again.
author: LT B.

description: This is the WORST Chinese Restaurant I think I have ever been to. My GF was finishing up a soccer game and the 1 line bus was stopped due to the biking people riding all over the city. We were starving and wanted to find the closest chinese restaurant. So we walked around and one of the ladies in there convinced us to go in because the prices seemed reasonable and fair and it seemed to be pretty crowded. When something is crowded you would think that a place is somewhat popular. With that said, we ordered a combo meal which seems pretty basic (Won Ton Soup, Pot Sticker, Monglian Beef, Chicken with Broccoli and Chicken Fried Rice for $10.99 each). We sat there waiting and waiting and it was literally 30 minutes and we still did not get any dishes. We were getting frustrated and we stood up and were about to leave until one of the workers said the food is coming. There food was not much better. Their Won Ton Soup was very plain and their pot stickers had no taste. Not only that, but when we got our beef and chicken dish it took them ages just to bring out the rice. What kinda chinese (even asian place) place serves their meat dishes before bringing rice out. Very unacceptable! I recommend never to come there ever!!
author: Nir B.

description: the food's okay, especially since its so cheap. i only come here to chinatown takeout, but you also get free soup with your order, even for take-out.
author: Jen P.
